q: Kimberly Strassel, it's not that. "At the heart of Mr. Donald Rumsfeld 's book is an important critique of the Bush administration that has been largely missing from the debate over Iraq," Strassel writes. The dominant narrative to date has been that a cowboy president and his posse of neocons went to war without adequate preparation and ran roughshod over doubts by more sober bureaucratic and strategic minds. But what Donald Rumsfeld described in his memoir is a tale of mismanagement, "one that holds individuals"- but not necessarily Donald Rumsfeld himself- "responsible for failures of execution," Strassel writes.

Each year certain power stations are required by federal law to shut down for regular maintenance in the winter when the power is usually on very low draw.
